supportDesc.support: A manuscript in multiple parts that largely consist of paper but with a few parchment leaves (ff. 73-74, 86, and 251-253). The manuscript also features parchment tabs on the outer margins of ff. 127, 143, and 213.

foliation.p: ?16th-century foliation with supplements by a 20th-century foliator
foliation.note: Numbering in brown ink in the upper right-hand corners of the rectos on ff. 51-253. A modern foliator has largely followed the historic folation but in order to 'correct' a gap in numbers between 12 and 15, they have crossed the latter number out replaced it with 13 in pencil. Similarly, they have replaced historic numbers 16-19 with 14-17. Perhaps in an attempt to 'remedy' a similar gap between 138 and 143, the modern foliator has crossed the historic folio number 138 out and replaced with the number 142. They have also corrected various duplicate numbers by adding an a to the second occurrence of the number: 81a, 188a, and 252a.

p.formula: 1eighteen | 212 312-2+2 (11th-12th excised and replaced) 412+1 (13th added) | 5-78 | 816 | 912-1 (12th missing) | 10-178 18two | 19?6-2 (?5th-6th missing) | 20-228 238-2 (7th-8th missing) | 24eight 25four

binding.p: 17th- or 19th-century brown speckled leather over pasteboards; the spine with 5 raised bands, gold tooled and with three paper labels, each containing a printed element of the alpha-numerical shelfmark: R, 14, 41.

acquisition.p: It is unknown when and how Trinity College acquired the manuscript. The College's current classmark (R.14.41) is inscribed in pencil on the inside of the upper cover, and in brown ink on f. 1r. The alpha-numerical elements are printed separately onto three paper labels pasted onto the spine. Its ex libris, featuring an engraving of its heraldic arms and name Coll: Trin: Cantab:) pasted onto the inside of the upper cover. Its library stamps on ff. 1r, 12v, 51r, 110v, 127r, 142v, 143r, 252v.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James, The western manuscripts in the library of Trinity College, Cambridge: a descriptive catalogue, 2 (1901); and Linne R. Mooney, Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge, The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist XI (Woodbridge: Brewer, 1995).

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.

monogr.title: The western manuscripts in the library of Trinity College, Cambridge: a descriptive catalogue
A Middle English Version of Lanfranc's Chirurgia Parva: The Surgical Part

analytic.title: The Arcus Charms and Christian Magic

monogr.title: Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge

The Middle English version of William of Saliceto's <hi rend="italics">Anatomia</hi>: a critical edition based on Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.41 with a parallel text of the medieval Latin <hi rend="italics">Anatomia</hi> edited from Leipzig, UniversitÃ¤tsbibliothek, MS 1177

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: An untitled recipe (f. 3r) has the name D. Bulleyn written over it, probably referring to the English physician William Bullein (b. c. 1515-1576) who published various medical works between 1558 and 1565. A recipe for the dropsy (f. 4r)is attributed to D. Langten, probably referring to the English physician Christopher Langton (1521-1578), fellow of King's College, Cambridge, and the College of Physicians of London, who published medical works between 1547 and 1552. The recipe may not be taken from his published works, however, since it seems to describe an eye-witness account of a medical treatment performed by Langton on a female patient (Mrs Egles) involving her being placed into a newly-dug pit and then being buried with sand taken from the bowling alley. A recipe for a gall or bladder stone (f. 8v) is attributed to Valentine Rawsworme the stranger surgion (and said to have been given to John Hinde). This probably is the Valentine Russwurin whose medical practices were critised by the London surgeon William Clowes (1543/4-1604) [on Russwurin, see Amanda Coates, 'Stories of Medical Malpractice in Elizabethan England', Synapsis(2022)] (with thanks to Peter Murray Jones for sharing his identification). A recipe for frenesie (f. 4r) is attributed to D. Atlone, who remains unidentified. A recipe for the stone (f. 11r) is attributed to D. Bayl, who remains unidentified.

All the recipes are directly medical except for a recipe for a wasshing ball (f. 9r), which involves Venetian soap (Sope of Venyse). A recipes for a washing ball can be found in Hugh Plat's Delightes for Ladies (London: 1600), involving castille soap.

msItem.title: Tract on the Four Humours
msItem.rubric: 12v for the 4. Compleccions how they do abouue in qualite as thus
msItem.incipit: 12v Blood is hot and moist / Fleamne is could and moist / Choller is hott and drye / Melancholy is could and dry
msItem.explicit: 12v And as bloud is \verye/ moist and hott and so much more is fleamne and could but as [...]

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: The collection contains A preciouse water for eyes Ã¾at be blinde, which involves a mixture of herbs, the powder of fifteen peppercorn seeds, white wine, honey, and fiue spoonfulls of maskuline childes vrine.

msItem.title: Two medical recipes
msItem.note: The recipes are for a grene wound and ffor to heale sores.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes for treating broken bones and sores

supportDesc.support: This part of the manuscript consists of paper leaves (ff. [i]-17, 111-126, 208-211, 243-252) and parchment leaves (ff. 251-253) that were added to the manuscript at four different locations in the 16th century. The paper is folded in folio. Folios [i]-17, 111-126, 208-211, and 245-250: Hand with five-pointed star and Owl.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint (occasionally), vertical lines of frame only. Single columns. c. 25-35 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Copied in several 16th-century cursive scripts with both anglicana and secretary features.

decoNote.p: This part of the manuscript does not contain any significant forms of decoration.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.41, ff. 51-81, 81a, 82-86

msItem.title: Chirurgia
msItem.author: Roland of Parma
msItem.textLang: Latin with marginal additions in Anglo-Norman
msItem.rubric: 51r Libellus de Chyrurgia Magistri Rolandi [added title]
msItem.incipit: 51r Hoc opus in .iiij.or particulis distinguendum \esse/ decreuimus
msItem.explicit: 86r Superponatur Storaci . et fiat in unctio inter tres ignes in ceruice . in collo . et spina . et in toto corpore
msItem.note: Added medical texts in Anglo-Norman in the margins on ff. 54v (lower margin), 55r (lower margin), 64r (single word in Latin recipe in lower margin), and 73v.

msItem.title: Method for testing for leprosy
msItem.incipit: 85r Si uis expereri de aliquo vtrum sit leprosus . fac eum expoliari et accipe peluim plenum aquam et proice contra dorsum eius

msItem.title: Note on the Chirurgia of Ruggero Frugardo
msItem.incipit: 86v Hoc opus in ordinem et lucem fuit ab aretino guidone logice professoris ministri rogatu carissimorum sociorum et egregij doctoris sui consensu ac desiderio anno ab . incarnacionis domini M.o C.o lxix. regnante gloriosissimo rege Willelmo feliciter. Explicit cirurgia magistri Rogeri Fugardi a magistro guidone arietino discipulo suo prosecuta et ab eius doctore laudata
msItem.note: Added by a different 14th-century hand. Full transcription as in James (1901), p. 327.

msItem.title: Medical recipe(s)
msItem.note: Four lines of Middle English text, written in the 15th century, that Mooney (1995), p. 40 takes as "headings for or beginnings of three medical recipes and a fourth note": ffayr rennende water and gret salt, Tak Ã¾e ball of wyn dreÈd and fenegre, Brend alum and reme of melk, and A pynte half a pound and ounce. However it is possible that these lines all relate to one another and consitute a single recipe.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in ? mixture of quarto and octavo with a few parchment leaves (ff. 73-74, 86). Folios 87-110: watermarks unidentified.

list.item: Quire 312-2+2 (ff. 63-74: 11th-12th leaves excised and replaced with parchment leaves)

catchwords.seg: One catchword written in the lower outer corner of f. 62v.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. Single columns. 29-31 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Copied by a single hand working in an anglicana script.

decoNote.p: Small and large (1-2 lines) plain initials in blue or red ink; the blue ones sometimes featuring minor forms of decoration in red ink.
Line-fillers consiting of horizontal red lines.
Paraphs in blue or red ink.
Small (1 line) regular initials highlighted with red ink.

provenance.p: Robert Beverley [Bewerlay] (fl. c. 1450-c. 1550) Beverley [Bewerlay], Robert, fl. c. 1450-c. 1550: his ownership indicated by two bookplate verses on f. 110v in which he refers to himself as Robart Bewerlea and bewerlay.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.41, ff. 87-110

msItem.title: Chirurgia parva
msItem.author: Lanfranc of Milan
msItem.rubric: 87r Incipit liber magistri lanfranci doctoris [added title: Chyrurgia parua Magistri lanfranci Mediolanensis]
msItem.incipit: 87r Intendens uenerabilis amici Bernarde componere librum in quo tradam omnium concedente datore plenam doctrinam ad instrumentum cyrurgicum pertinentem
msItem.explicit: 109v qui tibi donet graciam suam mihi aut peccatori ueniam peccatorum tribuat et uitam sempiternam qui est benedictus in secula seculorum amen
msItem.finalRubric: 109v Explicit parua cyrurgia magistri lanfranci mediolansis . Deo gracias

msItem.title: Liber de Naturis Rerum (extracts)
msItem.author: Pseudo-John Folsham (attributed elsewhere)
msItem.incipit: 109v De homine occiso - Homo transiens per cadauer hominis occisi licet eum non sentiat tamen horrore concutitur et hoc ex quanto locum que spiritu infectionem recipiente : et eam anime representantes
msItem.explicit: 109v Pytagoras attestans dicit quod a terra vsque ad lunam sunt .ccc. et .xxvij. stadiorum .a. luna vero vsque ad solem duplum . a sole vero vsque ad sydera fixa triplum
msItem.note: Extracts from the sections De aere et contingentibus aerem and De motu celi of Pseudo-John Folsham's Liber de Naturis Rerum. Abramov (2003) identifies four full-text copies of the work and one copy of an abbreviated and selected version. Among the former is one 14th-century manuscript: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.15.13. The extracts in this manuscript, however, were previously unidentified.

msItem.title: Collection of five medical recipes
msItem.note: Added in the 15th or 16th century. The last recipe for treating pain in the eye is accompanied by a drawing of an eye in dark ink.

msItem.title: Bookplate verse from an owner of this book (rubbed out)
msItem.incipit: 110v Y praye yow praye ffor me Robart Bewerlea in yower prayers dayly Ã¾at owthe this bocke ther on to loke it schall do bote
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 15th or 16th century but subsequently heavily rubbed out. Mooney (1995), p. 40, transcribes the owner's name as ? belgerley but this record follows the DIMEV in transcribing it as Bewerlea.

msItem.title: Bookplate verse from an owner of this book
msItem.incipit: 110v Pray ffor bew[er]lay [Mooney: belgerlay] Ã¾at owghe this bock / who lokes theron yt may do boot
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 15th or 16th century by two different hands: one hand has added the request for prayers and the other the verse that puts a curse on those who loose the book. Mooney (1995) transcribes the owner's name as Belgerlay but, as with the preceding bookplate verse, the name appears to read Bew[er]lay instead.

msItem.title: Book curse for losing the manuscript
msItem.incipit: 110v And who Ã¾at [l]osse \y/ tell god send hym yll hotte / tyll he brenges yt hom a gayne Ã¾an god losse hym of his pay[ne]
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added by a 15th- or 16th-century hand. This verse is not mentioned in Mooney (1995) nor recorded in the Index of Middle English Verse

msItem.title: Recipe for treating textiles
msItem.rubric: 110v ffor to make a gomied clothe
msItem.incipit: 110v To make a gemied clothe take half a quart of terpontyne perreson half a quart poche half a quart hors gres half a quart poude off comen ounce i off bayes ounce
msItem.explicit: 110v Ã¾ou put in the pouders and stor to yt be cold or wytt yt ys got kep on clos or put yt on ledder

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in ?octavo. Folios 87-110: Watermarks unidentified.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in frames of brown ink at the centres of the lower margins of the last versos of quires.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. Single columns. 28-30 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Folios 87r-109v (upper half) were copied by a single hand in a Northern Textualis script.
Addeditiosn to folios 109v (lower half)-110v were copied by five scribes wokring in cursive hands with both anglicana and secretaryfeatures.

decoNote.p: One large (12 lines) puzzle initial in blue and red ink on f. 87r.
Large (2 lines) plain initials in blue or red ink; the blue ones sometimes featuring minor forms of decoration in red ink.
Titles and sub-headings written in red ink.
Paraphs in blue or red ink.
Small (1 line) regular initials highlighted with red ink.

msItem.title: De Anatomia

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.41, ff. 143-188, 188a, 189-207

msItem.title: Chirurgia parva (Middle English translation)
msItem.author: Lanfranc of Milan
msItem.rubric: 143r The lasse boke of maister Lamfranke of Meleyne in Surgery
msItem.incipit: 143r Leue ffrende barnard I Èit wyll make a boke in whiche y wylle take by the helpe of god a fulle lore that failiÃ¾ to the instrument of surgery ne I thenk not in this werke to reherse the but shorte fewe and esaide medicines neuirthelesse for the grete nede I ne hold hym not feble but to hym thou myght fully tryste
msItem.explicit: 166v Ã¾u myÈt be a gude leche and in non oÃ¾er maner but god it wolde Ã¾e sende Ã¾orow his grace and Ã¾at grace Ã¾e god and to me synfull man forgyfnes of my synnes and lyf withowten ende Ã¾at is blyssyde in werlde withowten ende amen
msItem.finalRubric: 166v Here endeth Lanfrank his litle booke of surgery [added]
msItem.note: Not identified by Mooney (1995) who states that the text 'does not appear to correspond to ed. (EETS 102 (1894)) from BL Addit. 12,056 or Bodl. Ashmole 1396 [1]'. The latter two manuscripts, however, contain Middle English translations of Lanfranc's Chirurgia magna.

msItem.title: Chirurgia magna (Middle English translation)
msItem.author: Lanfranc of Milan
msItem.rubric: 166v Here bygynnyth Ã¾e boke nowe first of Ã¾e more tretice in surgerye of Maister Lamfronke of Mylane whiche is I clepid Ã¾e Antydotarie [Added title: tractatus 5tus practica Lanfranci
msItem.incipit: 166v In Ã¾e fyrste tretes wheche we clepen Ã¾e antidotarye we Ã¾enken to set medycyns semple and compownede Ã¾at bene nedefull to Ã¾is craft alls meche as falyÃ¾e to surgere and Ã¾ey i sett nou[g]t all for Ã¾ay bene withoutten ende ne Ã¾ey may be vnderstand of man neÃ¾erles I schall sett Ã¾o Ã¾e wheche I haue lernede of frendys and hauede of wemen and Ã¾is tretes holdeÃ¾e vij. chapiteles
msItem.explicit: 187r-187v Ã¾e forÃ¾e maner to molyfie in Ã¾ ij and in Ã¾e iij and Ã¾e forÃ¾e cace is a lone and is Ã¾at Ã¾u schalte haue Ã¾e water of seÃ¾ynge of floure and camomylle fenegreke and Ã¾e rotte of malaweuyss oÃ¾er thynges of the same kynde
msItem.finalRubric: 187v Explicit Lanfranc Chyrurgia completa seu potius eius tractat .5us.
msItem.note: Mooney (1995) notes that the text is apparently incomplete and that it does not correspond directly to the other known Middle English copies of the Chirurgia magna.

msItem.title: Anatomia
msItem.author: William of Saliceto
msItem.incipit: 187v All Ã¾ouÈe it by houeÃ¾e to determyne anothemye Ã¾e entencioun was not to nember all membres partyculerly Ã¾ouÈe olde surgens bene wonyd to deuide and nomber membres particulerly in to particuler membre
msItem.explicit: 207v ffor it shewithe opynly howe Ã¾e kuttynge of the empostems of those placis own to be cutte after the lengÃ¾e of Ã¾e legges and of the Ã¾yes and haue vpon Ã¾e hanches after the lengÃ¾e of Ã¾e spondelis of the reynes Ã¾e kuttynge own to ben don after Ã¾e lengÃ¾e of the body and the cauteryzes of Ã¾ese placis own to be don in the same maners after the goynge forthe of Ã¾ese membris. Amen - Deo gracias

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in octavo. Folios 143-207: Mons (three hills).

signatures.p: Quire signatures consisting of combinations of Roman numerals and the letter q (probably indicating 'Quire') written in the lower outer corners of the first rectos of quires.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords underlined with brown ink written in the lower inner corners of the last versos of quires.

p.seg: Ruled in ink, frame only. Single columns. 22-30 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Copied by a single hand writing in a cursive script with anglicana and secretary features. The same hand has copied ff. 213-242.

decoNote.p: Large (2 lines) initials in red ink.
Titles of works written in red ink.
Minor decorative flourishes on ascenders on the top line highlighted with red ink.
Regular (1 line) initials highlighted with red ink.
Paraphs in red ink.
Underlining in red ink.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.41, ff. 213-242

msItem.title: Treatise on remedies
msItem.textLang: Middle English recipes with a Latin heading and charms
msItem.incipit: 242v ffor ache and vanyte in Ã¾y hede take betoyne or werweyne or sillis or wormode and make leche Ã¾erof and wasche Ã¾y hede Ã¾erwith Ã¾ryse in Ã¾e weke
msItem.explicit: 242v and tak as mekell Ã¾eroff as wyll boile ayen alle Ã¾e grece and boile it all togedre and apan and drawe it thorouÈ a cloÃ¾e and do it in boxis and anoynt it Ã¾erwith
msItem.note: Treatise of remedies with 130 headings, each including several recipes.

note.p: The remedies include a gynaecological section, including a diagnostic for establishing the cause of unwanted childlessness in a couple: wheÃ¾er is defaute in man or woman Ã¾at she beres nougt (f. 239v), remedies for fertility issues: ffor to make a man and woman to gete children (ff. 239v), recipes to influence the child's sex: ffor to gete a sone (ff. 239v-240r), methods to establish the sex of an unborn child: ffor to wete wheÃ¾er she be with son or with dougther (f. 240r), a section of charms to help a pregnant woman deliver her child safely (discussed below), methods to deliver a stillborn child: ffor to delyuere a woman of dede childe (ff. 240r-240v), and a remedy for women who have purged excessively after giving birth: ffor Ã¾am Ã¾at purges Ã¾am ouere mekell after Childyng (f. 270v).
The collection also includes prognostic methods to establish whether patients will live or die: ffor to wete yf a seke man shall lyve or dye (ff. 240v-241r).

Among the remedies are various charms, including a charm for jaundice that involves liturgical formula written on a quartered apple (f. 228v: AnoÃ¾er take an appell and schere it in .iiij. parties and do away Ã¾e fert party and write in a party . In nomine partris et filij sui ihesus nazareni + and in Ã¾e toder partyt et spiritus sancti + et in Ã¾e Ã¾ryd party + rex iudeorum amen.; a charm for epilepsy (Falling Sickness) that instructs one to collect the herb mercury in the early morning of the feast of St John the Baptist, recite prayers over it, and then leave it on an altar until nine masses have been said over it (f. 229v): AnoÃ¾er tak on saynt John day Baptist or Ã¾e sone arise a gresse Ã¾at men calles mercuryall and Ã¾e whyle Ã¾ou drawes it vp sey Ã¾i pater noster and Aue maria and lay it on a Auter to .ix. masses be seyd ouere it Ã¾an tak Ã¾at gresse and drie it an make pouder Ã¾erof and gyf him to drink Ã¾at has nede Ã¾e weight of .iij. penys and he shall be hole for euere.

Another charm provides instructions for curing epilepsy with amulets onto which are inscribed the names of the Three Magi written in the patient's blood, and for making a prophylactic drink for children (ff. 229v-230r): AnoÃ¾er tak Ã¾e blode of Ã¾e litell fynger of him Ã¾at is seke and write Ã¾ese Ã¾re names of Coleigne Jasper fert aurum thus Melchior attrapa mirram he Ã¾at beres Ã¾e names of Ã¾ese .iij. kynges with him Ã¾an shall he be lessed Ã¾orouÈ pety of god of Ã¾at evyll. AnoÃ¾er tak and wryte with Ã¾e same blode Ã¾es Ã¾re names for saied and hange Ã¾a aboute his necke in a wryt. AnoÃ¾er make a childe drynk it wrytten or he be vj. Èere old and he shall neuere haue it; a charm for Ã¾e cramp (ff. 230v-231r: AnoÃ¾er geddre apoun gode friday at .v. parayssshe chirches .v. of Ã¾e fyrst penys Ã¾at is offeryd to Ã¾e crose of eche chirche Ã¾e first peny [sic] Ã¾e first peny Ã¾an tak [sic] Ã¾a[m] Ã¾am all and go be fore Ã¾e crosse and say .v. pater noster in Ã¾e worshippe of Ã¾e crosse and Ã¾e .v. woundes and bere Ã¾am ouer Ã¾e .v. daies and say day also mech on Ã¾e same wyse and Ã¾an gar make a rynge Ã¾erof withouten alay of oÃ¾er metell and write within Jasper balthar attrapa and write withouten ihesus nazarenus and Ã¾an tak it fro Ã¾e goldmyth apoun a friday and say .v. pater noster as Ã¾ou dyd before and vse it all way afterward

A section of charms to help a woman conceive a child (f. 240r): Here begynnes charmes for trauelyng of child. Arcus forcium super nos sedebit virgo maria notabit lux et hora sedule sedebit rebus rubus rarantibus natus nater natoribus faxs sic memor esto vt sit puer vel puella. Exiet foras qui Christus natus est nullum dolore passus est venit homo fugit dolor Christus adiutori adiuro te virgo per patrem et filium et spiritum sanctum vt habeas potestatem coniungendi say Ã¾is charme thryse and scho shall sone haue child and it be hir tyme. AnoÃ¾er say quicumque vult ouer hir and scho shall haue childe and it be hir tyme. AnoÃ¾er Beata Anna genuit mariam matrem domini nostri Jhesu Christi et sancta maria genuit Christum filium dei Annunciante gabriel archangelo per ipsam natiuitatem credo ego quod omnis Christianus a morte et ab omni periculo potest esse liberatus sancta maria dei genitrix et omnis sancti apostoli et omnes sancti martires et omnes sancti confessores et omnes sancti virgines ut intercedant pro famula dei amen. AnoÃ¾er tak and Ã¾ese wordes in buttur or chese and garhir ete sator arrepe to nete operarotas.

While Mooney notes that the collection's first recipes resemble those in the Liber de Diversis and can be compared with copies of this collection, the collection's previously unresearched charms suggest specific parallels with London, British Library, Royal MS 17 A VIII. Both manuscripts include the so-called Arcus charm (a hitherto unidentified copy appears on f. 240r) as well as the charm that opens with the words Beata Anna.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in octavo. Folios 213-242: Mons (three hills).

signatures.p: Quire signatures consisting of combinations of Roman numerals and the letter q (probably indicating 'Quire') written in the lower outer corners of the first rectos of quires.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords underlined with dark and red ink written in the lower inner corners of the last versos of quires.

p.seg: Ruled in blindpoint, frame only. Single columns. lines to the page.

handNote.p: Copied by a single hand writing in a cursive script with anglicana and secretary features. The same hand has copied ff. 143-207.

decoNote.p: Minor decorative flourishes on ascenders on the top line highlighted with red ink.
Regular (1 line) initials highlighted with red ink.
Paraphs in red ink.
Underlining in red ink.

note.p: An English index for the recipes in the treatise on in the treatise on ff. 213r-242v, organised alphabetically according to the names of ailments, was added by a 16th-century hand to the manuscript's final parchment leaves (ff. 251r-252a recto [See Part 1]).

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer in Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries, Cambridge University Library
